LGTM2. @artwr Shall we merge the PR?

Sorry I'm not familiar with venv. I renamed my commit messages to spell out virtualenv to avoid any confusion.

I did take a look at https://docs.python.org/3/library/venv.html real quick and saw:

> When a virtual environment is active (i.e., the virtual environment’s Python interpreter is running), the attributes sys.prefix and sys.exec_prefix point to the base directory of the virtual environment, whereas sys.base_prefix and sys.base_exec_prefix point to the non-virtual environment Python installation which was used to create the virtual environment. If a virtual environment is not active, then sys.prefix is the same as sys.base_prefix and sys.exec_prefix is the same as sys.base_exec_prefix (they all point to a non-virtual environment Python installation).

So I think `sys.real_prefix` is just a virtualenv thing. To support venv, we'd need to look at the above attributes.
Sorry should have said so earlier: please add unit tests.
Do we really get that many orphaned tasks? Cause that would be an issue with the executor.

There's not so many that I couldn't just manually clear them, but there's enough that it is a problem with airflow, and we should not count queued right now. FWIW, if you keep an empty queue this doesn't really make a difference.

I am not familiar with the docker-py package. The package on pypi has not been updated since November 2016 and the documentation of that package seems to point to the docker package documentation (https://docker-py.readthedocs.io/en/latest/)

I have manually installed the docker package and did not rely on dependencies from setup.py. That's how I found out.

Can someone shed a light on the difference between these two packages?
Welcome to the club!
@criccomini why was this closed?
+1 to get this PR merged. I'm trying to write a custom executor (AWS Batch) and without this, I'm stuck. Trying to find a workaround / may just clone this PR branch.

They are basically the same package. Prior to version 2.x it was called docker-py, and since version 2 they switched to docker.
They actually have issues open on their project to make it more explicit because it's been causing a lot of confusion.

@sdikby Thanks for the comment! As you mentioned, the previous PR did not handle the case that the target dag has subdag properly, so I revised it.
With the new PR, one can specify either a whole dag or just a subdag. For example, given the following DAG:

```
DAG_P: Task_A >> Task_B >> Task_C (both A and B are SubDagOperator)
Task_A: Task_a1 >> Task_a2
Task_B: Task_b1 >> Task_b2
```

* `airflow remove_dag DAG_P` removes all records related to DAG_P, including the ones related to DAG_P.Task_A and DAG_P.Task_B.
* `airflow remove_dag DAG_P.Task_A` only removes the records related to DAG_P.Task_A and remains the ones related to DAG_P itself and DAG_P.Task_B.
Ok. I'll make the dependency such that it checks if either docker-py or docker is installed. Installing the docker dependency (in setup.py) will pull down the docker package.

ok -- I know where to change the docker package dependency: line 125 of `setup.py`. Changing that to `docker = ['docker>=2.0.0']` will get us install the package docker.

But I am not sure how to validate if docker-py may be installed and rely on that version. I am new to python packaging.
I'm not sure if it's considered good practice, but you can import it in a try except and if it's present it won't throw.

@bolkedebruin Alex explained this to me offline, his logic makes sense. In the long run we want to revert this commit, but we can only do that when we have the guarantee that all running task instances have an active dagrun. At the moment things like triggering DAGs via the UI don't respect this and can cause problems, e.g. you queue a TI in a failed dagrun via the UI but it never actually runs, but it will still count against the concurrency. Alex is going to elaborate in the TODO he added for posterity.
